name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Introduction to Battlestar Galactica
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Introduction to Battlestar Galactica
long_desc: In 1982, Edward James Olmos played Detective Gaff in Blade Runner. Four years later, when offered the lead role on Star Trek The Next Generation, he turned it down. Why He didnt want to do any more scifi. Why, then, did Olmos agree to lead the reboot of Battlestar Galactica, a cheesy science fiction show from the 70s that earned most of its fans by coasting on Star Wars hype   Through the course of a semester, we attempt to answer this question, and in the process, explore Battlestar Galacticas impact on American society. This course is for everyone who wants to learn more about Battlestar Galactica. Whether youve watched no Battlestar Galactica, or all of Battlestar Galactica, this StuCo is a forum for fans to simply watch the show and talk about it. We will spend each class discussing a different topic in the Battlestar Galactica universe, discussing plot elements, behindthescenes fun facts, and the impact Battlestar Galactica had on pop culture.

custom_fields.goals: To understand the impact of Battlestar Galactica on the society of its time.To know how, in turn modern society impacts Battlestar Galactica.To understand the relationship between politics in Battlestar Galactica and realworld politics.
custom_fields.key_topics: The main topic will be the show Battlestar Galactica (2003) and its relevance to and impact on our current society and pop culture.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: No prior knowledge required. The class is designed to be accessible to even those who have never watched Battlestar Galactica.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Students will have weekly polls about the episode and in-class discussion as well as a midterm and a final. The midterm will be to play the Battlestar Galactica board game and the final will be a graded discussion. The grading scheme is 60% homework, 20% midterm, and 20% final.
custom_fields.relevance: This course explores ways that science fiction and politics interact through the lens of the television show Battlestar Galactica, allowing students to learn about morality, politics, and science while having fun watching television.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Readings will be available for students to learn more about the Battlestar Galactica universe and its connections to the the real world if they wish.
